[ğ“ƒ¾](ğ“ƒ¾) Î±  

The first letter 'alpha' in modern [Alphabet](Alphabet)s  

[Originally read al'Pha](https://www.academia.edu/25578233/Re-reading_the_letter_%F0%93%83%BE_al.phall_in_ancient_Hebrew), so not just 'a', but 'pha','fai'  

This is reflected in the Futhark, the rune alphabet:  

The Fe rune áš  (Old Norse fÃ©; Old English feoh) represents the f-sound in the Younger Futhark and Futhorc alphabets. It cognates to English fee, wealth, fee with the original meaning of Vieh : "sheep" or "cattle" (Dutch Vee, German Vieh, Latin pecum, Sanskrit pashu).

The f component was consistently 'lost' amongst many branches of the alphabet:  

ğ“Šª ğ“ ğ“‡¯ ğ“€­ Ptah > à¤¦à¤¿à¤µà¤¿ ftvi > [à¤¿](à¤¿.html) divi [deus](deus.html) sky  

ğ’€œ ğ’• ğ’€¸ [v]ad-da-aÅ¡ father á¼„Ï„Ï„Î± (Ã¡tta), Gothic ğŒ°ğ„ğ„ğŒ°

ğ’€œ ğ’‹« ğ’€¸ [v]attaÅ¡  

Likely it was just an orthographic convention: al'pha = [pha](alpha) at beginning of word.
